description: Probabilistic Error Amplification (PEA) is a noise scaling technique that amplifies errors by learning the actual noise model of the device and then probabilistically injecting additional Pauli errors in proportion to the learned rates.

Unlike folding or pulse stretching, PEA uses a data-driven approach: it first characterizes the noise via sparse Pauli-Lindblad tomography, then uses this noise model to inject errors that accurately amplify the existing noise profile.
This technique was a key component in IBM's demonstration of utility-scale quantum computation, enabling accurate ZNE on circuits with over 100 qubits and thousands of gates.
how_it_works: Perform sparse Pauli-Lindblad noise learning on the device to characterize per-layer noise channels.
The noise learning involves: (1) Pauli twirling of two-qubit gate layers, (2) repeating identity pairs of layers to characterize noise, (3) deriving fidelity values for each noise channel.
To amplify noise by factor λ, inject additional Pauli errors sampled from the learned noise model.
Execute circuits at multiple noise levels (λ = 1.0, 1.3, 1.6, etc.) and extrapolate to λ = 0.
The learned noise model ensures amplification matches the actual hardware noise profile.

key_equations.label: Noise amplification
key_equations.latex: \text{Inject Pauli errors with rates proportional to } (\lambda - 1) \times \text{learned rates}

advantages: Accurate noise amplification using the actual learned noise model
Targets the specific error processes present on the hardware
Avoids exponential sampling overhead of PEC
Demonstrated effectiveness on utility-scale circuits (127+ qubits)
disadvantages: Requires upfront noise characterization (sparse Pauli-Lindblad learning)
Noise model may drift over time, requiring periodic recalibration
Assumes noise is well-described by sparse Pauli-Lindblad model
More complex implementation than folding-based methods
use_cases: Circuits where folding-based scaling is inaccurate
IBM Quantum hardware with Pauli-Lindblad noise learning support
